title-group.article-title: Review: microbial metabolites – a key to address gut inflammation and barrier dysfunction in the premature infant

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Preterm birth interrupts the development of the human gastrointestinal tract, resulting in an immature permeable gut barrier with increased risk of intestinal pathology, such as necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The gut microbiota metabolize dietary components into bioactive metabolites that play a crucial role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis. While the roles of microbial metabolites have been studied in relation to adult gastrointestinal diseases, their specific impact on preterm infants remains unexplored. This review aims to identify how microbial metabolites interact with the developing gut barrier in preterm infants, focusing on their role in gut inflammation and NEC. Metabolites include short-chain and conjugated fatty acids, indole derivatives, bile acids, polyamines, and polyphenolic compounds. An overview of the unique features of the premature gut barrier physiology is provided, including perinatal developmental changes in cellular structure, cell junctions, and the gut microbiome. Potential benefits and molecular mechanisms of microbial metabolites in the premature intestine and environmental factors responsible for NEC are discussed. In summary, microbiome-derived mediators have the potential to strengthen preterm gut barrier integrity and alleviate inflammatory stress. Further research may reveal clinically relevant preventative or therapeutic treatment targets for NEC in preterm infants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The human gut is a highly specialized interface between the external environment and the host, which has a significant impact on human health. The gut lining exerts a complex dual function incorporating barrier defense against environmental factors as well as selective barrier permeability for dietary components. Preterm birth interrupts the development of the human gastrointestinal tract during the final trimesters of pregnancy, resulting in an immature permeable gut barrier with increased risk of intestinal diseases.1 A mucosal layer, submucosal immune system, and epithelial cell layer form a chemical, immunological, and physical barrier against potential pathogens, food antigens, or toxins.2,3 Simultaneously, the gut barrier allows for transport of essential molecules to provide nutrients to the host.2 This requires maintenance of a multi-layered signaling system based on dynamic epithelial barrier integrity, a balanced symbiotic relationship with commensal bacteria, and an adequate immune response.2 The premature gut barrier is characterized by a low production of mucin,4 a dysfunctional integrity of the epithelial layer of the gut,5 and an insufficient intestinal immune response.6

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a life-threatening inflammatory condition in premature infants, leading to acute intestinal ischemia and necrosis. NEC is the prevailing cause of morbidity and mortality in 5–7% of preterm neonates and 10–15% of very low birth weight infants.7,8 Surgery is required in approximately 50% of affected infants, with associated mortality rates of up to 51%.9 Despite the fulminant course of surgical NEC and research investigating its pivotal role in premature infants, specific treatment strategies have yet to be established. The pathogenesis of NEC is multifactorial and characterized by gut barrier dysfunction due to an imbalanced interplay between mucus production, epithelial (enterocyte) cell integrity and immune response.10,11

Microbial metabolites are produced by the gut microbiota and have a pivotal role in gastrointestinal maturity, pathogen colonization, gut barrier integrity, and host metabolism.12 Active metabolites can have a direct impact on the gut barrier by upregulating tight junction proteins (TJs),12 altering cellular metabolism, and modulating the immune response to inhibit or promote inflammation.13 Microbial metabolites have been reported to play a central role in intestinal barrier function and associated inflammatory and metabolic diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), celiac disease, and colon cancer.11,14,15 However, their role in the premature intestinal barrier poorly investigated.11

We postulate that microbial metabolites and the associated molecular mechanisms that play a role in adult intestinal inflammation may also have an impact on the premature gut barrier and NEC pathogenesis. This review aims to explore how microbial metabolites may interact with the developing gut barrier in premature infants. Applying concepts from the role of microbial metabolites with adult intestinal physiology could reveal new insights into NEC pathogenesis and treatment.

sec.title: Intestinal immaturity and gastrointestinal development
sec.p: The gastrointestinal tract develops during the second and third trimester of pregnancy with tremendous growth of the intestine, increasing one-thousand-fold in size from gestational weeks 5 to 40.16 Small intestine growth continues into adulthood, reaching an approximate length of 575 cm by age 20 years, with a total surface area of 200 m2. Interrupted development in infants born prematurely can severely impact structural and functional maturation of the gastrointestinal tract. The underdeveloped nervous system delays intestinal transit, facilitating bacterial overgrowth and abdominal distension due to increased fermentation and gas production.17 This stasis, in combination with a premature barrier characterized by low protective mucus, decreased secretory immunoglobulin A production, and reduced regenerative capabilities increase the risk for inflammation and tissue damage.17 An immature gut immune system and increased gut barrier permeability predispose neonates for bacterial translocation, intestinal inflammation, and NEC.16,17

The intestinal barrier is comprised of three layers: a luminal mucus layer, an epithelial layer, and a submucosal immune system of the gut, all of which work to provide physical and immunological protection11 (Figure 1). The selective permeability of the gut barrier allows the passage of beneficial metabolites such as nutrients and electrolytes while protecting against pathogenic bacteria and toxins.11,18 Premature intestine shows deficiencies in all three of these layers, leading to insufficient host defense and activation of inflammatory cascades. Figure 1.
Intestinal barrier anatomy and physiology.Structure and function of the mature intestinal barrier (left) and known premature barrier physiology (right). The layers of the barrier consist of the intestinal lumen, mucus layer, epithelial lining, and lamina propria. The epithelium shows enterocytes, goblet cells tuft cells, enteroendocrine cells, and Paneth cells. The structure of cell junction is demonstrated in the left bottom corner.Alterations in barrier physiology specific to the premature intestine are listed on the right.IAP = Intestinal alkaline phosphatase; NEC = Necrotizing enterocolitis

sec.title: Luminal mucosal layer
sec.p: The mucosal layer of the intestinal barriers is composed of glycoproteins formed from the secretion of mucins by goblet cells.11 The presence of pathogens in the intestinal environment can stimulate release of mucins by the goblet cells to increase protection against infections and parasitic invasions.19 Secretion of interleukin (IL-25) by tuft cells triggers subsequent release of IL-13, a cytokine that promotes a hyperplastic response by goblet cells to increase mucin release.11 Furthermore, goblet cells release antimicrobial peptides and are able to provide intestinal immune cells with antigens via Goblin cell-associated antigen passages.20 The premature mucosal layer is characterized by a reduced capacity of goblet cells to produce mucin, resulting in a thinner mucus layer and increased barrier permeability as well as inflammation.4

sec.title: Epithelial layer
sec.p: The epithelial layer consists of a single layer of epithelial cells and cell junctions and has a central role in gut barrier regulation.11 Some of the most important specialized intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) include enterocytes, Paneth cells, goblet cells, enteroendocrine cells, and tuft cells.11 In addition to their individual functions, they collectively play a role in maintenance and regulation of intestinal barrier permeability. The presence of these cells forms a polarized monolayer which functions to separate the intestinal lumen from the underlying lamina propria.18 Due to the impermeability of the IEC cellular membranes to hydrophilic solutes, these molecules are unable to cross the barrier without the use of specific transporters.18 The epithelial structure consists of crypts and villi, with proliferating intestinal stem cells (ISCs) that are high in Leucine-rich repeat-containing G-protein coupled receptor 5 (LGR5) expression at the crypt base. LGR5 marks actively dividing stem cells in the intestinal crypts, essential for intestinal development. The cells differentiate, progressively migrate to the villus tip, and then slough into the intestinal lumen via anoikis (apoptosis), which ensures epithelial renewal of eventually damaged cells every 5 days.21 The crypt-villus architecture in preterm infants has not yet been fully organized and enterocyte differentiation is not yet localized in the base of the crypts.20 At 10 weeks gestation, LGR5 expression can be demonstrated throughout the intestine and enterocytes differentiate from stem-cell-like cells that are low in LGR5.20 At 12 weeks, LGR5+ progenitors have started to organize in crypt bases and increase in frequency until 19+ weeks of gestation.20 In preterm infants, the epithelial layer still consists of an abundance of ISCs and reduced numbers of differentiated specialized epithelial cells, which contributes to barrier dysfunction.20,22

Enterocytes and their corresponding junctional proteins create the physical barrier of both the small and large intestines.11 Enterocytes are also responsible for absorption of nutrients and their reciprocal metabolization, further enhancing their role in regulation of intestinal permeability.11,19 Following nutrient acquisition, enteroendocrine cells are responsible for the release of peptide hormones for regulation of digestive processes of the gastrointestinal system.23 These processes are essential for nutrient metabolism and to provide the body with the necessary energy to carry out its basic functions. Protection against pathogens is a crucial function of some IECs. The production of antimicrobial peptides by Paneth cells is essential for regulating intestinal homeostasis by protecting against pathogenic species.11 Paneth cells are located at the base of the small intestinal crypts in proximity to intestinal stem cells.21 They secrete lysozyme, phospholipase A2, and antimicrobial peptides (defensins α and β) as well as cathelicidins to regulate microbiota composition.21 Defensins released into the intestinal crypt by Paneth cells can induce chloride secretion from neighboring enterocytes to flush potential pathogens away from the sensitive stem cells.21 Paneth cells can be found at 13.5 weeks of gestation at a low density which gradually increases until term.24 During their cell development at 20–28 weeks of gestation, cathelicidin expression decreases significantly, which is associated with a higher susceptibility to NEC. Compared to age-matched controls, premature infants have fewer and mostly underdeveloped Paneth cells that are not immunocompetent,25 which leads to an altered microbiome and increased risk for inflammation.

In addition to the specialized epithelial cells of the intestinal immune system, cellular junctions regulate the passage of molecules between cells of the gut barrier.18 These junctional complexes can be categorized as TJs, adherens junctions (AJs), and desmosomes.18 TJs are located on the apical surface of the epithelium and contain proteins necessary for maintenance of cell-to-cell adhesion and molecular transport.11,18 Occludins, zonula occludens (ZO), and claudins are integral membrane proteins of the TJ complex. TJs of the premature gut are characterized by an immature composition and function, suspectedly involving occludin–claudin interaction, which may increase barrier permeability in preterm infants.26

Occludin is a 65 kDa protein and was identified as the first TJ strand component.27 Occludins exert a regulatory function rather than being responsible for TJ strand formation.28 In occludin gene knockout mice, TJs remained present, but mice showed significant defects, such as chronic gastritis, hearing loss, brain calcifications, male infertility, and failure of females to adequately suckle pups.28

ZO and claudins are integral to the maintenance of the apical epithelial structure of the TJ complex.28 In ZO-1 and ZO-2 knockout epithelial cell lineages, gut barrier function was impaired due to the inability to recruit claudins to the TJ complex.28 Claudins form pores to regulate permeability of the complex.29 Despite initial loss of barrier maintenance and disrupted cytoskeletal organization in ZO-1/ZO-2 knockout cells, function was restored by increasing ZO-1 expression and reinstating claudin binding.28

Along with TJs and their peptide components, AJs and desmosomes function to maintain epithelial structure and thus play a role in intestinal barrier permeability.18 AJ proteins consist of cadherins and catenins, while peptide components of desmosomes include desmoglein and desmocollins.11 The inhibition or deficiency of the protein components of both AJs and desmosomes has been shown to cause worsening of the integrity of the gut barrier. Specific to AJs, inhibition of the E-cadherin-catenin complex results in weakening of the intestinal mucosal barrier.11 In desmosomes, deficiency of desmoglein 2 results in loss of epithelial layer integrity in the gut barrier.11

The intestinal barrier is supposed to tighten and become more selectively permeable in early postnatal maturation independent of gestational age. Commensal bacteria induce expression of genes that improve intestinal barrier function and abnormal colonization can disrupt this process. Therefore, premature neonates with abnormal intestinal microbial composition do not have postnatal maturation of this critical protective barrier, leaving the neonate susceptible to entry of microbes, toxins, inflammation and injury.

sec.title: Submucosal immune system
sec.p: The subepithelial region consists of the lamina propria (composed of immune cells), the enteric nervous system, and connective tissue. This area is colonized with B and T cells, eosinophils, dendritic cells, mast cells, macrophages and more. The gut immune cells are organized into lymphoid structures such as lymphatic follicles, Peyer’s patches and mesenteric lymph nodes. There is an extracellular matrix of the lamina propria that is supported by connective tissue produced by fibroblasts. Finally, there is an enteric nervous system with neurons and glial cells that form the myenteric plexus and the submucosal plexus. This system coordinates the interaction between the central nervous system and the intestine. While the epithelial barrier offers physical protection, mucosal immune function is required to mount a response to harmful antigens. Impairment in the intestinal immune system and its interaction with gut antigens can lead to inflammation and disease.

The immaturity and level of development of the gut barrier is a crucial factor in the pathogenesis of intestinal disorders such as NEC in the premature infant. Table 1 explores the differences in the premature versus the mature intestinal barrier. The complex interplay between the structural and immunological components of the premature gut barrier is a key area of investigation, as its dysregulation plays a significant role in the development of neonatal intestinal disease.Table 1.

sec.title: The premature gut microbiome
sec.p: The gut microbiome is essential for the function of the intestinal system and protection against infection; however, it is underdeveloped in the premature infant. Several factors that are unique to the premature infant influence the development and diversity of the microbiome of the premature intestinal tract. Colonization and maturation of the infant gut microbiome typically occur in a stepwise fashion, with deviations implicated in several health impairments in childhood and adolescence. Infants born before 37 weeks’ gestation have a unique set of microbial colonization patterns as well as frequent clinical interventions that modify the gut microbiome.36 These alterations can subsequently increase the vulnerability of the preterm infant to developing NEC.

sec.title: Establishment of the neonatal gut microbiome
sec.p: Increasing evidence suggests that the neonatal gut microbiome already develops in utero.37,38 It is therefore potentially altered by both prenatal and postnatal factors, such as microbial composition within the placenta and amniotic fluid, antenatal antibiotic exposure in utero, or postnatal microbial transfer of bacteria through breast milk.37,38

The infant’s microbiome during the first two months of life is dynamic, commonly shows sudden shifts of bacterial populations, and follows a choreographed pattern at varying rates dependent on gestation at birth.39 A fast increase in facultatively anaerobe Proteobacteria, such as Gammaproteobacteria, Escherichia and Klebsiella, is followed by their slow decline and a continuously increasing proportion of strictly anaerobic bacteria, such as Bifidobacterium spp.39,40

A universal microbial signature deviating from this early development pattern that is predicting the onset of NEC or defining NEC itself, however, has yet to be identified.38,41 Gut microbiome diversity and a high proportion of Bifidobacterium spp. has been associated with reduced risk of NEC onset.41 Furthermore, an association between NEC and strains of the anaerobic toxin-producing Clostridium perfringens has been found.42 In infants born at less than 27 weeks’ gestation developing NEC, an increased proportion of facultatively anaerobe Gammaproteobacteria and a reduced proportion of strictly anaerobic Negativicutes were demonstrated.39 Strictly anaerobe Bifidobacterium spp. and Bacteroides spp. were also reduced in preterm infants during the first six weeks of life.6 The My Baby Biome study revealed that even in term infants in the United States, a lack of Bifidobacterium spp. can drive gut dysbiosis and changes metabolic signatures.43 The interplay of microbial composition, gut inflammation and NEC pathogenesis has yet to be clarified. One mechanism suggests a dysregulation of inflammatory responses in the preterm gut due to Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) activation by gram-negative lipopolysaccharides.44 Strain-specific differences between bacterial species add even more complexity to the microbial network, as different bacterial strains drive development of different gut community types and therefore altered stool metabolite profiles.40

Apart from alterations of the preterm gut microbiome, an altered gut virome preceding NEC onset also suggests NEC-associated gut virus-bacteria interactions, particularly related to Acinetobacter, Clostridium, Lactobacillus and Haemophilus.44 Current evidence, however, is still lacking detailed analysis of overall virome composition and development.

sec.title: Neonatal intensive care unit admission
sec.p: Neonatal microbiome development is affected by time spent in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for several reasons. First, many NICU patients are exposed to antibiotics, both via maternal administration and postnatal prescription, affecting the colonization of the intestinal tract. Additionally, the use of medical devices such as feeding tubes increase the risk of pathogenic colonization of microbes.45 Acid suppression medications, which are commonly utilized in the NICU, have been associated with considerable changes in the diversity of the microbiome in infants.46 The longer the NICU stay, the additional risk of exposure to hospital-acquired pathogens that inhibit the ability of native bacterial species to colonize the intestine.45 These exposures lead to increased bacterial instability and lowered microbial diversity, leaving the neonate vulnerable to intestinal disease.45,47 Proteobacteria often dominate the infant’s gut microbiome during the first weeks of life in the NICU and are associated with NEC onset during the further course.48 A clear understanding of iatrogenic factors predisposing infants to alterations in gut microbiota is necessary to minimize risk in the intensive care setting.

sec.title: Oxygen therapy
sec.p: In preterm infants, oxygen therapy is a common treatment due to breathing difficulties or underdeveloped lungs – both hypoxia as well as hyperoxia, however, are associated with detrimental health risks.49 Oxidative stress has been demonstrated to provoke ‘oxygen radical disease’ including several disease manifestations, such as retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or NEC.50 Additionally, respiratory support in premature infants affects the microbiome, causing a relative abundance of aerobic and facultative anaerobic bacteria.51

The Neonatal Oxygenation Prospective Meta-analysis (NeOProM) compared oxygen saturation target levels in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) including premature infants born <28 weeks’ gestation.52 Lower oxygen saturation (85–89%) was associated with increased death and risk of surgical NEC, while higher saturation (91–95%) reduced risk of ROP.52 Furthermore, lower cerebral tissue oxygenation throughout NICU admission was demonstrated in infants with NEC compared to infants without NEC.53

sec.title: Analgesia and sedation
sec.p: Many infants in the NICU require medications for analgesia and sedation. Opioid exposure can cause changes in gut development, gut motility and variability in the microbiome. Suggested mechanisms for this in animal models include alterations in bacterial metabolites, including short-chain fatty acids, bile acids, and bacterial diversity.54 Evidence is limited on the use of sedative medication in the intensive care setting as a risk factor for NEC. Sedation-associated complications including mechanical ventilation, feeding delays, or hemodynamic changes, may indirectly affect NEC. Prenatal opioid exposure causing neonatal abstinence syndrome has been proposed as a risk factor for NEC in infants with late gestational age onset NEC (born >35 weeks).55

The French prospective population-based study EPIPAGE2 analyzed NICU-associated treatment strategies during the first postnatal week in infants born at <32 weeks’ gestation and their association with NEC.56 Adjusted strong risk factors for NEC were hemodynamic failure requiring volume resuscitation, reduced gut motility, and anesthesia by sevoflurane for catheter insertion.56 Sedation with morphine, fentanyl, or Sufentanil, however, showed no increased or even a reduced NEC risk.56

sec.title: Mode of delivery
sec.p: Mode of delivery impacts transfer of maternal microbiota to the fetus and thus influences microbiome diversity in the neonate. Vertical transfer is a phenomenon which describes the passing of maternal vaginal microbiota to the fetus as the child descends through the birth canal.57 For neonates born via Cesarean section, horizontal transfer is the term used to describe the delivery of bacteria to the neonate via skin-to-skin contact with other individuals in the environment.57 With vertical transfer of vaginal delivery, infants have a microbiota characterized by high levels of Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, Prevotella, and Bacteroides, which are members of the phyla Firmicutes, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes.57,58 Neonates born via Cesarean section have an intestinal microbiota with higher composition of Staphylococcus, Corynebacteria, and Propionibacterium, with low levels of Bifidobacterium and Bacteroides.57,58 Studies have found protective effects correlated with the Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus genera typically found in gut microbiota of vaginally delivered neonates.57 In contrast, the Staphylococcus-rich and Bifidobacterium-poor microbiome of neonates born via C-section have pathogenic potential.57 The variation in composition of microbiomes dependent upon method of delivery also corresponds to decreased bacterial diversity in infants delivered via C-section.57 Vaginal dysbiosis with a decrease in vaginal lactobacilli and higher proportions of anaerobes, however, can potentially increase NEC risk also after vaginal delivery. Current evidence shows contradictory results concerning the impact of mode of delivery on NEC onset. Prospective studies focusing on the distinct characterization of the infant’s and mother’s microbiome are necessary to identify potential associations.

sec.title: Neonatal diet
sec.p: Feeding protocols are an essential component of neonatal care, especially for premature infants and those admitted to the NICU. While oral enteral autonomy is the goal, not all infants achieve this.59 Feeding methods must be adjusted to account for neurologic and gastrointestinal function. The neurologic underdevelopment in infants born before 34 weeks gestational age creates difficulty coordinating reflexive responses such as sucking, swallowing, and breathing.60 Because of this, premature infants are typically gavage fed, as the tube supplies nutrients directly to the stomach.60 The susceptibility to gastrointestinal diseases such as necrotizing enterocolitis has been associated with variations in feeding methods of neonates.

Breast milk provides oligosaccharides, metabolites, and other factors, such as heat-sensitive proteins, that regulate microbiome development.61–64 A randomized controlled trial demonstrated that mother’s own milk is the primary factor in shaping the preterm infant gut microbiome, with an even bigger impact on weight gain or microbial diversity than milk fortifier type or antibiotic exposure.65 Specifically, oligosaccharides can promote colonization of the gut barrier with Bifidobacterium and Bacteroides, which have protective effects on neonatal health and development.57 Increased growth of beneficial bacteria, due to their more efficient utilization of oligosaccharides compared to potential pathogens, has been demonstrated.66 Cesarean section influences lactogenesis and delays the establishment of breastfeeding. Donor milk is an effective substitute often used for preterm infants that do not have access to maternal milk. However, donor milk and formula ultimately lack some nutrients, bioactive compounds, or live cells that have shorter shelf life or bioavailability.67 These perturbations in microbiome development due to feeding modality and source can leave the infant susceptible to NEC. The relationship between feeding methods and microbiome composition is integral to epithelial barrier homeostasis and neonatal health. Recent research suggests that breast milk microbiota may affect the infant’s microbiome and NEC risk.68 Further studies investigating the differences in bioactive components of breast milk between mothers and the association with disease development are necessary to gain insight on NEC risk factors due to feeding modality, and to understand why human milk is protective, yet not eliminating NEC onset.

Parenteral nutrition (PN) is a standard practice for nutritional support of preterm infants when full enteral feeds cannot be safely provided.69 Many studies have shown that PN dramatically changes the microbiome, causing a low abundance of Firmicutes and a high prevalence of Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria phylum, as well as Actinobacteria phylum and Akkermansia muciniphila.70 Bacteroidetes phylum can cause intestinal inflammation and increase intestinal permeability, driving a bacterial flux across the mucosa and resulting in a cytokine-mediated hepatocellular injury. Additionally, PN increases the growth of opportunistic pathogens including E. coli, Salmonella, Yersinia, Helicobacter and Vibrio, and decreases the abundance of commensal microbials such as Bacteroides fragilis.70 These changes also affect gastrointestinal immunity, making the infant more susceptible to intestinal diseases such as NEC.

sec.title: Antibiotic exposure
sec.p: Maternal and neonatal antibiotic exposure commonly stems from both preventative and treatment-based measures perinatally. Due to an increased risk of infection, a range of 30–50% of premature neonates receive some form of antibiotic therapy.71 Additionally, more than 40% of pregnant individuals receive an antibiotic prior to delivery.72 Preventative antibiotic treatment is typically targeting Group B Streptococcus (GBS), or it is administered as a preoperative infectious prophylaxis before C-section.72 Neonatal GBS has been known to cause sepsis and meningitis, while maternal GBS has created complications such as chorioamnionitis, sepsis, and endometritis.72 Approximately 10–30% of pregnant individuals have GBS present in the vagina or rectum, thus intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis lowers the rate of transfer to the fetus during vaginal delivery.72 Early onset disease (EOD) GBS is characterized as occurring within the first week following birth and has a higher incidence in neonates whose mother was GBS positive.72 Since a GBS culture takes 48–72 hours to produce results, it is not feasible to determine maternal GBS status during labor and thus recommendations state GBS testing should occur around 35–37 gestational weeks.72 Therefore, GBS status is unavailable for premature infants. As a result, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is standard of care to reduce the risk of development of EOD GBS.72 Due to the common use of maternal and fetal antibiotic therapy during various stages of pregnancy, it is important to consider the effects of this regimen on the intestinal health of the neonate, specifically regarding the composition of their gut microbiome.

Both prenatal and postnatal antibiotic exposures have been associated with potential effects on the formation and diversity of gut microbiota in neonates. In a study conducted on newborn mice, the impact of antibiotic treatment on gut microbiome diversity, intestinal barrier function and permeability, and susceptibility to NEC-modeled injury was examined.71 The results showed a reduced microbiota species diversity in mice treated with antibiotic therapy as compared to controls.71 Additionally, when pups treated with antibiotics were exposed to pathogenic bacteria (induced experimental NEC), increased permeability and inflammatory cytokines in the intestine were identified.71 Another study was performed to compare the gut microbiome of 30 premature infants with that of 176 term infants using meconium and stool samples collected over the first six weeks of life.6 Abundance of beneficial Bifidobacterium and Bacteroides were significantly lower following newborn antibiotic therapy in preterm versus term infants, with even lower levels in very premature children born at <28 weeks’ gestation.6 These results suggested that early gestational age is associated with reduced bacterial diversity and potential pathogenic growth. Dantas et al. demonstrated that meropenem, ticarcillin-clavulanate, and cefotaxime were associated with decreased species richness and all antibiotic treatments enriched the presence of resistance genes and multidrug resistant organisms.73 Furthermore, the duration of antibiotic therapy has a significant impact on dysbiosis, which can increase risk of NEC. A higher risk of dysbiosis with reduction of Bifidobacteria and Staphylococci has been demonstrated in preterm infants undergoing antibiotic courses for seven days.40

sec.title: Probiotics
sec.p: Probiotic administration in neonates is a controversial topic. Several randomized controlled trials and cohort studies have reported that the supplementation of probiotics can reduce the incidence of NEC. Probiotic strains, specifically belonging to the bacterial genus Bifidobacterium, can significantly shift the composition of the preterm microbiome, accelerating maturation and facilitating health-promoting changes in immune and metabolic parameters.36 A meta-analysis including 73 studies explored the association between probiotics and NEC and found that overall incidence and mortality were decreased.74 The results need to be interpreted cautiously. There is significant variation in probiotics available, with differences in species, dose and time of administration. We currently lack a pharmaceutical-grade probiotic product that has been studied in very low birth weight infants. Further standardization, surveillance and research need to be done to ensure safe and effective use in preterm infants.

sec.title: Premature gut barrier dysfunction
sec.p: In addition to intestinal immaturity and delayed gastrointestinal development in the premature gut, several mechanisms contribute to barrier dysfunction.75,76 Here, we present an overview of the key mechanisms implicated in gut barrier dysfunction in the premature infant and their role in NEC.

sec.title: Toll-like receptor 4
sec.p: TLR4 is a bacterial receptor that plays a pivotal role in the innate immune response by detecting lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a component of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria. TLR4 is expressed on the cell surface of IECs and macrophages and is associated with crypt stress and proinflammatory immune cell recruitment.4,77 Overactivation of TLR4 has been implicated in NEC, triggering a proinflammatory immune response and apoptosis in intestinal crypts.11,77,78 Bacterial peptidoglycan and its fragments are sensed through pattern recognition receptors (PRR), with TLR4 being the most common receptor on IECs, macrophages, and dendritic cells.79 Highly expressed during the prenatal period, TLR4 supports gut development and intestinal stem cell proliferation.79 Its expression physiologically decreases after birth and may induce an overshooting proinflammatory response ultimately leading to bowel necrosis and sepsis in preterm infants.79 The TLR4/Nuclear Factor kappa B (NF-κB) signaling pathway has been proposed as a crucial mechanism for hypoxia-induced barrier damage, bacterial translocation, and sepsis.11 The proinflammatory immune response is accompanied by dysfunctional epithelial cell interactions, including dysregulation of the cadherin-catenin-cytoskeleton interface.80 It also has a role as part of the ROCK1–TLR4–NF-κB signaling pathway in macrophages and induces a more proinflammatory macrophage phenotype by increasing glycolysis.81,82 Overall, TLR4 has a critical role in intestinal inflammation and the pathogenesis of NEC.

sec.title: Mucin
sec.p: Impairment in the mucosal layer plays a key role in barrier dysfunction. The mucosal barrier is the first line of defense that protects the host against bacterial translocation and entry of other potential pathogens.83 Mucus consists of secreted as well as transmembrane mucins and is produced by the goblet cells.83 It functions as a physical barrier as well as a protective lubricant that prevents epithelial damage.83 Mucins can provide an energy source for bacteria capable of degrading it and an imbalance between biosynthesis and degradation can change the microbiome and induce inflammation.83 Expression of mucin genes (MUC) is affected in NEC.83,84 In goblet cells of preterm infants with NEC, expression of transmembrane MUC1 as well as of secreted MUC2 is impaired compared to non-NEC preterm children.4 MUC1 plays a role in lubrication, protecting cells, maintaining stickiness, identifying cells and maintaining the functional integrity of epithelial cells. It can also participate in intracellular signal transduction and immune regulation. When the intestinal epithelium is damaged, there is a large release of MUC1 to repair in the intestinal mucosa. The impaired function and secretion of MUC1 in preterm infants with NEC is thought to play an important role in the pathogenesis.

sec.title: Intestinal alkaline phosphatase
sec.p: Intestinal alkaline phosphatase (IAP) is a mucosal defense enzyme that is produced specifically by enterocytes, exerting antibacterial and anti-inflammatory effects.4 IAP deficiency is associated with dysbiosis and increased gut barrier permeability, pointing out the importance of IAP to maintain gut barrier function.4 IAP can detoxify lipopolysaccharides (LPS) and prevent bacterial adherence and growth.4 It exerts anti-inflammatory effects in a TLR4-dependent manner and plays a significant role in NEC.85–87 In rat pups with NEC, IAP expression was decreased and enteral IAP administration reduced intestinal injury caused by LPS.87 IAP is also believed to promote intestinal bacterial diversity thanks to its ability to dephosphorylate nucleotide triphosphates. A reduction of IAP leads to decreased bacterial growth.32 Furthermore, IAP decreases intestinal permeability. Studies with IAP knock out mice have shown significant downregulation of TJ proteins and increased intestinal permeability.32 Overall, IAP is involved in dysbiosis, intestinal integrity, and perfusion and plays a role in several molecular mechanisms that contribute to NEC development.

sec.title: GLUT
sec.p: The GLUT family of membrane proteins is responsible for monosaccharide transport across the intestinal barrier and consists of 14 different isoforms encoded by the solute carrier transporter 2 (SLC2) gene.88 The GLUT2 and GLUT5 have been shown to play a role in intestinal inflammation and microbial regulation in colitis rat models.88 While GLUT5 gene expression was downregulated in small intestine of rats with iodacetamide-induced colitis,88 the intestinal-specific deletion of GLUT2 in rats led to improvement of inflammation and to an increase in commensal bacteria.88 In preterm children with NEC, small intestinal GLUT2 and GLUT5 protein expressions were decreased.4

sec.title: Paneth cell-specific lysozyme
sec.p: Most of the functions of Paneth cells are related the products they secrete such as antibacterial products, lysozyme, and a variety of antimicrobial peptides that aid in blocking the invasion of pathogenic microorganisms. Paneth cells are the primary source of lysozyme, a β-1,4-N -acetylmuramoylhydrolase which targets bacterial cell walls. Paneth cells and Paneth cell-specific lysozyme gene expression are lowest in preterm infants, increased in full-term infants, and highest in adults.4 Lysozyme can be found in saliva, tears, and breast milk, and can therefore be transmitted vertically from mother to infant.89 Lysozyme achieves bactericidal action by processing the bacterial cell wall and destroying the permeability of the bacterial cell membrane.90 Without Paneth cells, lysozyme is reduced, and the host is unable to resist invasion by foreign pathogens. In NEC, when intestinal mucosal inflammation occurs, Paneth cells are stimulated to release a large amount of lysozyme to kill harmful pathogens and mediate homeostasis of the intestinal flora.91 Due to diminished numbers of Paneth cells in preterm infants, the lysozyme response is not strong enough to prevent intestinal injury and is only measurable during the recovery phase.4,89 Additionally, murine studies showed reduced Paneth cell numbers were associated with dysbiosis involving overgrowth of gram-negative bacteria, such as E. coli.4 In summary, the premature infant is exposed to pathogenic factors before the developing Paneth cells can reach their full protective potential, leaving neonates susceptible to disruption of the intestinal tract and NEC.

sec.title: Peptide defensin alpha 6 (DEFA6)
sec.p: Another antimicrobial molecule produced by Paneth cells is the peptide defensin alpha (DEFA6).4,92 DEFA6 mRNA levels are detectable at 13.5–17 weeks of gestation in the small intestine but have very little expression until the middle of the third trimester.93 Enteric DEFA6 mRNA levels are significantly lower in newborns than in adults, along with fewer numbers of Paneth cells in the crypts. Additionally, surgical specimens of infants with NEC showed lower DEFA6 levels than controls.4 Sufficient DEFA expression seems to contribute to inflammatory homeostasis and may be important in understanding NEC pathogenesis.

sec.title: The role of microbial metabolites in the premature gut barrier
sec.p:
The gut microbiota metabolizes dietary components into active metabolites that directly regulate human physiology including gut barrier function (Table 2). Studies elucidating the functional activities of metabolites on gut barrier integrity and immune function in inflammatory diseases are expanding. While these studies have been performed in adults in diseases such as IBD, colitis, colon cancer and more, we believe their role would be similarly beneficial in the premature gut, and potentially consequential in the pathogenesis of NEC.Table 2.

sec.title: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
sec.p: SCFAs are considered a subtype of dietary microbial metabolites, as they are produced following fermentation of dietary fiber and undigested carbohydrates by Bifidobacterium, Lactobacillus, Enterococcus and Bacteroides.11,102 In preterm infants with NEC, the microbiome predominantly consisted of the phyla Proteobacteria and Firmicutes, with small populations of Bacteroides and Actinobacteria of <2%. Overall, the abundance of anti-inflammatory SCFA producing bacteria in NEC patients was found to be reduced.103,104 In patients with IBD, microbiota show enrichment of certain bacterial species, such as facultative anaerobe Enterobacteriaceae, including adherent-invasive Escherichia coli in the terminal ileum and the loss of obligate anaerobic producers of SCFAs.15 A commonly reported commensal bacterium with anti-inflammatory SCFA production capacities that is decreased in ileal Crohn’s disease is the clostridium Faecalibacterium prausnitzii.104 A reduction of this major member of Firmicutes is associated with postoperative and endoscopic disease recurrence at 6 months.104,105 In NEC, Firmicutes was one of the dominant phyla, however, the relative proportion of beneficial gram-positive organisms, such as Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, was only found in a minority of cases.103 In healthy adults Faecalibacterium prausnitzii makes up to 15% of the total fecal microbiota and is therefore representing one of the most abundant bacteria.106

SCFAs affect diverse cell types via cell surface G-protein coupled receptors (GPRs), SCFA transporters, and several intracellular targets, inducing a variety of cell type-specific effects.107 Three key metabolites classified as SCFAs are propionate, butyrate, and acetate, all of which play a role in immune cell differentiation and protection against foreign pathogens.11,77 SCFAs derived from bacterial carbohydrate and amino acid fermentation, particularly butyrate, activate IAP gene expression and alter the luminal pH, further affecting its function.108,109 Butyrate also has a significant impact on cellular metabolism and generally inhibits glucose metabolism in epithelial and immune cells. This has been shown by decreased GLUT1 expression in colorectal cancer cells, which is associated with increased levels of butyrate inhibiting glucose metabolism.110 Limited glucose metabolism enhances a more anti-inflammatory environment, particularly via anti-inflammatory polarization in macrophages (Figure 2). Furthermore, SCFAs are associated with increased MUC2 expression and may serve as an anti-inflammatory mediator preventing inflammation and cancer development111 (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Microbial metabolites as multifaceted mediators in small intestinal barrier dysfunction.Small intestinal barrier integrity is balanced by a network of microbial metabolites that are mediators in every layer. These are examples of effects exerted by short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), lactate, conjugated fatty acids (CFA), and indole derivatives in mucus, epithelial and submucosal layers.SCFA bind to G-Protein-Coupled Receptors (GPR41, GPR43) on enterocytes and inhibit proinflammatory cytokine expression via the NF-κB pathway (i.e. TNFα) as well as inflammasome activation and interleukin (IL)-1β production. Additionally, SCFA increase tight junction gene expression (occludin, claudin, zonula occludens 1 and 2 (ZO-1/2). SCFA and lactate further regulate enterocyte regeneration and proliferation, partially through Forkhead box O3 (FOXO3). SCFA increase MUC2 expression and therefore mucus production in goblet cells by inhibiting histone deacetylase (HDAC). In macrophages, SCFA additionally induce M2-like macrophage polarization via peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα).Conjugated fatty acids (CFA) activate PPARγ in macrophages and CD4+ T-cells.The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) is activated by indole derivatives, such as urolithin A. AhR enhances barrier integrity by increasing tight junction expression (occludin, claudin, zonula occludens, ZO-1/2) in enterocytes.SCFA = Short-chain Fatty Acids; CFA = Conjugated Fatty Acids; ZO = Zonula Occludens; NF-κB = Nuclear Factor kappa-B; TNFα = Tumor Necrosis Factor alpha; IL = Interleukin; STAT3 = Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription 3; FOXO3 = Forkhead box O3; MUC2 = Mucin 2; HDAC = Histone Deacetylase; PPAR = Peroxisome Proliferator-activated Receptor; NLRP3 = Nod-like Receptor Protein 3; AhR = Aryl hydrocarbon Receptor

In the infant’s gut, SCFAs are suspected to exert anti-inflammatory effects by altering DNA and histone methylation of proinflammatory genes102 (Figure 2). Immunomodulatory effects are induced through inhibition of histone deacetylases and enhanced acetylation of signaling molecules, such as the serine/threonine kinase p70 S6 kinase.107 Furthermore, SCFA-derived acetyl coenzyme A affects citric acid cycle catabolism and promotes mTOR activation, a central pathway regulating immunity, inflammation, and gut barrier integrity.112,113 Butyrate can reduce inflammation via the development of Treg cells.104 It specifically regulates intestinal permeability through activation of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), which in turn induces assembly of TJs, such as ZO-1 and occludin, critical for barrier integrity.11 Excessive luminal butyrate production by pathogenic bacteria, such as Clostridium perfringens (C. perfringens), C. difficile, C. paraputrificum, C. butyricum, and Klebsiella pneumoniae (K. pneumoniae), however, may reduce gut barrier integrity and may contribute to inflammation in infants with NEC.102 This may be aggravated by poor gastrointestinal motility in preterm infants, which increases luminal lactose fermentation, resulting in increased butyric acid production.102 In a NEC model using quails, high butyrate levels produced by C. butyricum enhances gene expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), which induces mucosal injury.114

SCFAs also affect the Phosphoinositide 3-Kinase (PI3K) signaling pathway, which is an upstream activator of RhoA/Rho kinase 1 (ROCK1), a critical regulator of barrier function in NEC.80 ROCK1 promotes inflammation in IBD by increasing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in vascular endothelial cells and by provoking M1-like macrophage polarization.82 In NEC, ROCK1 upregulation leads to increased intestinal permeability due to instability of the cell adhesion molecule E-cadherin.80 Neonatal mice fed butyrate showed reduction in intestinal injury by inhibiting TLR signaling via Notch1.115

sec.title: Tryptophan metabolism
sec.p: Tryptophan is an amino acid found in diets rich in red meat, fish, egg, cheese, cruciferous vegetables and beans. Maternal breast milk, donor breast milk and formula all have tryptophan; however, maternal breast milk has the highest concentrations. Tryptophan is catabolized into indole by tryptophanase which is expressed by microbes such as Clostridium sporogenes. These indole derivatives are essential for cell-to-cell communication. Tryptophan is a key modulator of the neonatal microbiome as its indole metabolites have direct effects on immune cells and gut barrier permeability.11,116 IEC expression of the rate-limiting enzyme in tryptophan metabolism, indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1), has a significant impact on the metabolism of tryptophan by gut microbiota to generate indole metabolites.117

Reduction of the tryptophan metabolites indoleacrylic acid and indole-3-lactic acid (ILA) is a feature in IBD and NEC.103,118,119 Indoleacrylic acid is produced by commensal Peptostreptococcus spp. and ILA can be produced by Bifidobacteria.104,119 Indole and indole-containing derivatives exert anti-inflammatory effects by activating the intracellular aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) or pregnane X receptor (PXR), expressed in IEC and innate immune cells.11,101,116 This induces immune cell maturation, increases TJ protein expression, and even reverses hypoxia-induced gut barrier dysfunction in mice.11 In an IBD model using mice, anti-inflammatory host caspase recruitment domain family member 9 (CARD9) gene expression altered microbiome composition, decreased microbial tryptophan metabolism, and increased intestinal inflammation.120 Card9−/− mice demonstrated reduced microbial tryptophan metabolism into AHR ligands, which increased intestinal inflammation.120 In a human organoid and a primary human NEC cell line model, ILA reduced proinflammatory cytokine expression of IL-8 following an IL-1β stimulus.119

Furthermore, indole derivatives that stem from bacterial tryptophan metabolism can increase MUC2 expression and strengthen the intestinal barrier by upregulating tight junction proteins and inducing anti-inflammatory cytokine expression.11,111 This is achieved by regulation of the AHR and pregnane X receptor (PXR), which makes them potential targets in IBD and carcinogenesis.11,111 A preventative approach has been reported in a NEC mouse model by AHR activation during pregnancy, which led to reduced TLR4 signaling independent of leucocyte activation.101 Part of this mechanism shown in mice was AHR activation using indole-3-carbinol (I3C), which inhibited downstream pathways via NF-xB.101 We therefore state that indole derivatives may represent promising therapeutic compounds in NEC and that further research should investigate their barrier strengthening effects, particularly through the AhR-dependent pathways.

sec.title: Bile acid metabolism
sec.p: Bile acids are steroid-based molecules produced by the liver that aid in fat digestion, absorption, and gut microbiome regulation. Primary bile acids, such as cholic acid (CA) and chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA), are synthesized in the liver from cholesterol. Secondary bile acids are modified by gut bacteria through dihydroxylation and deconjugation and include deoxycholic acid (DCA), ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) and lithocholic acid (LCA).11,121 The bacterial genera Bacteroides, Lactobacillus, and Bifidobacterium contain bile salt hydrolase necessary for secondary bile acid production.122 Additionally, gut bacteria can form further bile acid derivatives in the colon through dehydrogenation and epimerization reactions that may function as signaling molecules.123 Bile acids exert complex metabolic effects through the two canonical receptors, the Farnesoid X Receptor (FXR) and Takeda G Protein-Coupled Receptor 5 (TGR5).124 Apart from other noncanonical targets, these receptors and associated pathways have been studied in cardiometabolic, inflammatory, and neoplastic diseases.124 FXR contributes to gut barrier integrity, decreases inflammation and oxidative stress, and functions as a tumor suppressor in colorectal cancer.125

In patients with active IBD, defective bile acid metabolism led to deconjugation, transformation to secondary bile acids, and desulphation.126 Primary bile acids, such CA and CDCA, were increased in patients with IBD, while the secondary bile acids LCA and DCA were decreased.127 Due to the ongoing microbial colonization of the gut and immature liver function in premature infants, bile acid metabolism is significantly altered and accumulation of toxic bile acid metabolites may enhance intestinal injury in NEC.128,129

Research investigating the molecular effects of bile acids on intestinal barrier function showed that CDCA and LCA had opposing effects on integrity of the intestinal epithelium in human T84 cells.11 CDCA decreased levels of occludin and thus led to increased gut barrier permeability.11 No changes in barrier function were observed with sole treatment with LCA, yet LCA was shown to decrease CDCA-induced barrier permeability when present together.11 In mice receiving a high-fat diet to examine the effects on gut barrier function in relation to levels of the secondary bile acids DCA and UDCA, a DCA-supplemented feeding regimen increased gut barrier permeability as compared to controls.11 Further studies using cell models showed that DCA and CDCA increased barrier permeability, but there were no significant changes with UDCA.11 DCA and CDCA influenced barrier integrity via autophosphorylation of endothelial growth factor, dephosphorylation of the occludin protein, and reorganization of the cellular TJs.11 The function of bile acids and their isoforms may play a central role in NEC and regulatory effects may vary depending on the specific bile acid isoform and the environment of the host. In an NEC rat model, ileal luminal bile acids were associated with ileal damage and levels positively correlated with disease incidence and severity.130 Measured bile acid levels, however, did not distinguish between primary and secondary bile acids and their respective functions during NEC development.130 In preterm infants with NEC, results on the composition of bile acids compared to healthy controls are inconclusive.122,131 A higher coefficient of variation in total bile acid levels before NEC onset, however, has been postulated as a potential predictive clinical marker.131

FXR activity, a nuclear bile acid receptor with a major role in bile acid metabolism, is reduced in patients with IBD and FXR gene expression has been found to be decreased in inflamed mucosa of the colon.125 Recent evidence from a NEC rat model, however, showed that elevated FXR expression was associated with intestinal inflammation and ileal damage, suggesting an FXR-mediated mechanism specific for NEC.122 FXR is also a regulator of intestinal barrier integrity by mediating TJ composition in intestinal inflammation.132 We therefore postulate that overexpression of FXR in NEC may provoke bacterial translocation through dysregulation of TJ synthesis, such as claudin-1, occludin, and ZO-1 expression.

sec.title: Conjugated fatty acids
sec.p: Conjugated fatty acids are microbial metabolites produced by various intestinal bacteria to further regulate gut homeostasis by affecting gut barrier TJs.11 The intestinal bacteria Bifidobacterium, Enterobacter, and Lactobacillus, among others, produce conjugated fatty acids, such as conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), from dietary fats.11 In a mouse colitis model using dextran sulfate sodium (DSS), treatment with CLA led to upregulation of the tight junction proteins ZO-1, occludin, claudin-3, and E-cadherin 1 as compared to controls, thereby enhancing gut barrier function.11 In experimental IBD using mice, dietary CLA isomers decreased intestinal inflammation and prevented colorectal tumor formation in a Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ)-dependent manner.133 In patients with Crohn’s disease, CLA suppressed proinflammatory cytokine production in CD4+ and CD8+ T cell subsets.134 A similar mechanism has been reported in NEC, with CLA exerting anti-inflammatory effects via upregulation of PPARγ and therefore prevention of NFκB pathway activation.135 CLA is also a potent activator of other PPARs, such as PPARα, which have a major role in cellular metabolism and macrophage polarization.136 Therefore, conjugated fatty acids may be key immunomodulatory targets in NEC by reducing proinflammatory cytokine production and cell recruitment of leukocytes via the PPARγ/NFκB pathway.

sec.title: Polyamines
sec.p: Polyamines are small, positively charged organic molecules essential for cell growth, gene regulation, gut homeostasis, and immune function. Three main forms of polyamines are putrescine, spermidine and spermine.137 The individual roles of polyamines in intestinal diseases, are yet to be identified. Polyamines are produced by a wide variety of bacteria, such as Escherichia coli or Pseudomonas species, through decarboxylation of precursor amino acids directly into polyamines or other intermediates.138 Escherichia coli colonization in germ-free mice led to an increase in IEC polyamine levels in colonocytes and accelerated epithelial renewal.137 Furthermore, bacterium-derived putrescine was associated with a higher proportion of colonic anti-inflammatory macrophages, suggesting an immune-modulating role of polyamines in inflammatory disease.137 Spermidine exerted anti-inflammatory and barrier-protective effects through macrophages and IECs in a protein tyrosine phosphatase non-receptor type 2 (PTPN2) dependent manner.100 Furthermore, polyamine depletion in IECs was associated with lower expression of the cell-to-cell adhesion protein E-cadherin through a c-Myc-dependent mechanism, leading to increased gut barrier permeability.11 In patients with ulcerative colitis, genes related to polyamine metabolism have been identified and correlated as predictors for progression of the disease and potential therapeutic targets.139 Additionally, polyamine-nanoparticles exerted anti-inflammatory effects in an ulcerative colitis mouse model.140 The role of polyamines in NEC pathogenesis is currently poorly understood, but elevated levels of fecal cadaverine and putrescine concentrations in healthy premature infants may point toward a potential inflammatory role of polyamines in neonates.141

sec.title: Polyphenolic derivatives
sec.p: Polyphenols are naturally occurring plant-based antioxidants that are metabolized by beneficial genera, such as Bifidobacteriaceae and Lactobacillaceae.142 Bioactive compounds derived from the metabolism of polyphenols influence gut health, inflammation, and oxidative stress. There are a wide variety of polyphenolic derivatives with diverse anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, metal chelation, and neuroprotective properties.143,144 An important class of secondary polyphenolic metabolites produced from dietary ellagic acid are urolithins, with urolithin A (UroA) exerting an important regulatory role in intestinal inflammation and epithelial injury.11 A mouse model using mice fed with a polyphenol-rich diet following DSS treatment, including one rich in ellagic acids, demonstrated that UroA can alleviate colitis and improve gut barrier function in an IL-22 dependent manner.145 Furthermore, a complex crosstalk between microbiome and macrophages has been identified in these mice. Implantation of bone-marrow-derived macrophages into macrophage-depleted colitis mice led to declining intestinal inflammation with decreased levels of TNF-α and IL-1β, and increased IL-10 levels in colonic tissue.145 Apart from regulating cytokine expression, UroA showed beneficial effects on tight junction proteins and intestinal barrier function in mice.11 Expression of claudin-4, ZO-1, and occludin tight junction proteins was increased in an AHR-Nrf2-dependent manner.11 Additional exploration of the impact of UroA on gut function has been performed using colon epithelial T84 cells.11 Cytotoxicity in T84 cells following treatment with inorganic arsenic was reduced when cells were simultaneously treated with UroA, with a significant decrease in formation of reactive oxygen species, lactate dehydrogenase activity, and intestinal barrier permeability.11

The beneficial effects on the intestinal microbiome, cytokine profiles, tight junction proteins, and gut barrier function suggest a key role of microbial metabolites in NEC prevention and treatment. Preventive treatment had the largest impact on preterm neonate gut bacteria modulation and the development of a mature microbiome.14 A randomized controlled trial on microbiota administration routes in preterm infants showed that probiotic administration at the age of 7 days with Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium genera sufficiently modulated gut microbiota.1 Bifidobacterium supplementation led to beneficial effects through SCFAs only when infants were simultaneously fed with human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs).14 These findings support the postulated NEC-preventive role of breast-feeding in preterm infants as bacterial HMO conversion is reduced by formula feeding.14

sec.title: Microbial composition and the possible impact on NEC pathogenesis and treatment
sec.p:
Inflammatory mechanisms described in intestinal pathologies, such as IBD or colorectal cancer, are mediated by microbial metabolites. Investigating overlaps in disease-related inflammatory pathways and cellular interactions helps to identify downstream differences in disease pathogeneses and therefore NEC-specific mechanisms. The microbiome orchestrates metabolome-related inflammation and gut barrier integrity, which makes microbial metabolites and microbiome composition a potential target in NEC pathogenesis and treatment. Potential metabolite-based therapeutic implications in NEC are given in Table 3.Table 3.

sec.title: Microbial SCFA production and effects of SCFA on gut barrier function
sec.p: Microbes that indirectly or directly produce SCFAs are reduced in NEC. Probiotic therapy for NEC prevention has been postulated as most effective when containing Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus, both anaerobic bacteria producing SCFAs.157

Diet and microbial composition are the main factors regulating SCFA production, with breast milk or dietary fiber content increasing SCFA concentrations.147 Bacterial populations are balancing their community by metabolizing and providing certain SCFAs via cross-feeding, which promotes an anti-inflammatory environment.107,158

Probiotic supplementation containing bacteria and yeasts that increase SCFA production, such as Bifidobacterium, Lactobacillus, and Saccharomyces genera, has been postulated to prevent NEC and decrease NEC-related mortality in preterm infants.159 In mice, butyrate supplementation increased intestinal mucin and tight junction-related gene expression and decreased proinflammatory cytokines.147 Thus, SCFA-promoting microbiota in preterm infants could improve gut barrier integrity and promote an anti-inflammatory environment, protecting against NEC. A first clinical trial investigating fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) as a prophylaxis for NEC in preterm infants is currently pending (NCT06333405). Further studies are necessary to investigate the impact of SCFAs in the preterm gut and their role in NEC prevention and therapy.

sec.title: Bile acid-modifying microbiota and FXR-NLRP3 signaling
sec.p: Certain bacteria, such as clostridia, can modify bile acids which enhanced bile-acid-related epithelial damage in an experimental NEC model using rats.150 In this model, Clostridium scindens did not show NEC-promoting effects in the absence of bile acids, suggesting a particular role of bile acid-modifying microbiota in NEC pathology.150 Bacteroides, Lactobacillus, and Bifidobacterium, which are beneficial in NEC, contain bile salt hydrolase (BSH), an enzyme central in bile acid metabolism.122 In rats, BSH activity in B. fragilis was associated with reduced microbial dysbiosis and improved bile acid metabolism by inhibiting the FXR-NLRP3 signaling pathway.122 Therefore, B. fragilis has been proposed as a potential therapeutic in infants.122 The role of bile acid-modifying bacteria in premature infants and their effects on NEC, however, are yet to be investigated.

sec.title: Tryptophan-metabolizing microbiota and indole-derivative crosstalk
sec.p: Bacteroides, Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, and certain Clostridium strains produce immunomodulatory and gut barrier protective indole derivatives.160 Overall, more than 85 bacterial species express tryptophanase, which metabolizes dietary tryptophan resulting in indole production.161 Particularly, Lactobacillus produces ILA-derived tryptophan, which induced growth of other tryptophan-metabolizing bacteria and subsequent production of other indole derivatives, such as IPA and IAA.162 This ILA-mediated cross-feeding could reverse dysbiosis due to Citrobacter rodentium or DSS in mice.162 Indoles reduce intestinal inflammation and improve gut barrier function, but also function as signaling molecules between bacteria. Depending on the concentration of the respective indole derivative, it affects formation of spores, maintenance of plasmids, drug insensitivity, or toxicity.163 Tryptophan metabolism is complex and many bacterial species contribute either directly or indirectly by producing only certain types of indole derivatives, enhancing downstream reactions in tryptophan metabolism, or by promoting growth of other bacterial species that are involved in this multi-level crosstalk.163 Probiotic therapy with Bifidobacteria to produce ILA from tryptophan in breast milk has been proposed as a potential therapeutic strategy in preterm infants with NEC.119 Clinical trials are necessary to investigate the therapeutic role of certain bacteria that are involved in indole production in premature infants with NEC.

sec.title: Lactate and linolenic acid
sec.p: An imbalance of lactate-producing bacteria, such as Lactobacillus, Streptococcus, or Bifidobacterium, and lactate-metabolizing microbiota, such as Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes phyla, can lead to lactate accumulation.164 Elevated lactate levels have been proposed as a potential cause of NEC in premature infants.164 In contrast, Lactococcus lactis and Lactobacillus reuteri, both lactic acid-producing bacteria, have been demonstrated to be beneficial in NEC rabbit and NEC rat models.165,166 These contrary findings may be caused by the dual role of lactate in gut barrier function, where balanced lactate levels enhance barrier function, while lactate accumulation can have destructive effects.102 This suggests that a physiological balance of lactate-producing and lactate-utilizing microbes is necessary to achieve protective effects in infants with NEC. Further studies are needed to investigate the potential role of bacteria affecting lactate levels in NEC.

sec.title: Role of viruses and fungi in microbial composition
sec.p: Nonbacterial microbiome constituents, such as viruses including bacteriophages and fungi, have been shown to affect microbial composition in preterm infants.167 Like the gut microbiome, the gut virome varies between infants and undergoes dynamic changes during the first year of life.44,168 Recent evidence also describes co-transmission of bacterial strains together with viral strains from mother to child.168 Compared to the maternal gut virome, infant viromes include more active bacteriophage populations that decrease over time.168 This might point toward a specific role for phage-bacteria interactions during the first weeks of life and therefore for NEC onset. In preterm infants with NEC, a relative abundance of the bacteriophage families Myoviridae, Podoviridae and Siphoviridae was found.44 Furthermore, Escherichia and Streptococcus were proposed as relevant strains correlating with NEC-associated viral contigs.44

The effect of the gut virome on NEC development is subject to current research yet still underexplored. Apart from FMT, fecal virome transplantation (FVT) or fecal filtrate transplantation (FFT, involving viruses, metabolites, and cell debris without bacteria) are gaining attention.169 These methods could potentially be used as a therapeutic strategy in NEC by transplanting bacteriophages that enhance production of NEC-protective metabolites via phage-bacteria interaction in preterm infants.

Similar to the bacterial gut microbiome, eukaryotic fungi forming the mycobiome show reduced diversity in preterm infants compared to term infants.167 In contrast to the bacterial populations, however, the mycobiome in healthy individuals in general progresses in complexity rather than in diversity and abundance.167 Despite gut fungi representing only 0.01%–0.1% of the gut microbiome population, their cell size can be more than twice as large compared to bacteria, which makes fungi a significant part of the microbiome by size.170 The term infants gut is mainly colonized by Saccharomyces, Candida, and Malassezia spp., while preterm infants’ microbiomes are often dominated by Candida species.167 Fungi–bacteria interactions can form microbiomes and exert immunomodulatory functions, making the mycobiome a potential target in NEC.167,170 Fungal β-glucan has recently been postulated as beneficial in murine NEC by reducing intestinal inflammation and improving gut barrier permeability, probably by inhibiting the TLR4-NF-κB signaling pathway.146

sec.title: Barriers to progress
sec.p: NEC is a rare, multifactorial disease which leads to heterogeneous study populations with variable diagnostic criteria and confounding factors.171 Studies are therefore underpowered to draw strong conclusions and RCT design is challenging due to required sample size and standardized diagnostics and treatment despite multi-center collaborations. Furthermore, the collection of timely biospecimens in premature infants for mechanistic studies is technically demanding due to critical care priorities, poor gut motility, and extremely small blood volumes.172,173 Particularly, measuring microbial metabolites within small volume samples is challenging, as samples have to be collected using standardized techniques at predefined time points and have to be stored and processed in a timely manner to minimize variation.174 To link gut microbiome profiles with clinical intervention, alternative models of the neonatal gut are used – but cell line or animal models are particularly weak in resembling the preterm gut physiology, and mechanistic findings can often not be translated into the clinical setting.173 Organoid models derived from LGR5-positive stem cells in intestinal crypts have been developed over recent years, as well as intestinal organoid cultures from embryonic stem cells and intestinal fragments from aborted fetuses.173 These culture models, however, lack a gut microbiome, and their accuracy in resembling effects of microbial metabolites on the premature gut barrier has yet to be demonstrated.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Dysfunction and dysregulation of the immature intestinal barrier in preterm infants have been demonstrated as risk factors for the development of NEC. Microbial metabolites exert central anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects in various intestinal diseases, including C. difficile colitis, IBD, colorectal cancer, and NEC. The potential of microbiome-derived mediators, such as SCFAs or polyphenolic derivatives, to establish gut barrier integrity and reduce oxidative or inflammatory stress may provide promising target mechanisms in preterm infants with intestinal disease. To date, no preventative or therapeutic treatment targets have translated into clinical practice. The multifactorial pathogenesis of NEC, complexity of molecular interactions within the intestinal barrier, and necessity to utilize animal models for mechanistic studies are current challenges in NEC research. Microbial metabolites are widely demonstrated to regulate inflammatory processes and may play a key role in diagnosis, prevention, and early treatment of NEC. Further research on the impact of bacterial species, associated metabolites, and the intestinal inflammatory state is crucial to gain insight into preterm gut barrier dysfunction and NEC pathogenesis and in identifying microbial metabolites as effective treatment strategies.
